Graphs and UEFA Nations League

Test

Posted on September 27, 2018

Introduction

Recently I watched television and I stumbled across some sport report. Nothing special. It was about football and to be precise about the UEFA Nations League”. In short terms there exists four leagues (A, B, C, D) with three or four groups consisting of national teams. A is the highest ranked league and D the lowest. Each team in a group competes against each other for two times(First and second leg). The goal is to rise up to the highest league A. A game plan of all matches was shown and this was the moment that caught my eye. There so many matches and I wondered how they could determine each match in a group. I realized that this is a problem in graph theory. Luckily I read about approximation algorithms for the Edge Coloring Problem in the book The Design Of Approximation Algorithms and somehow I managed to relate the problem of determining matches in UEFA Nations League to the Edge Coloring Problem. So I want to dive deep more into this certain problem.

What is the Edge Coloring Problem?

So what is this problem? At first I want to give a more informal definition. Let’s say you have a graph and the minimum amount of colors given. The challenge is to color the edges of graph such that no adjacent edges have the same color. If you look each node independently, every incident edge has a different color. So this problem is ideally suited to solve different scheduling problems.

NP-Complete

How much time does it take to find a optimal edge coloring for any graph that has any chromatic index? The chromatic index is the smallest amounf of color of a edge colored graph. Unfortunately this problem is NP-complete. As a certificate you can use the graph and colors for each edge. This can be easily checked in linear time, if the coloring is valid. Thus this problem lies in NP. Next we need to reduce a known NP-hard problem to the Edge Coloring Problem. For instance we can reduce the 3-SAT problem, which is a known NP-complete and is stated as followed. Given a set of clauses and variables , where each clause consists of 3 literals , each clause is connected with an -operator and each literal inside a clause with a -operator. Each literal is either or for . The problem is to determine, if all clauses are satisfied. A clause is satisfied, if one of the variables in the clause is true.

Reduction

So the goal of the construction is that iff the instance of 3-SAT is satisfied, then is the constructed graph 3 edge colorable. I will only give you an idea how a construction from 3-SAT to Edge Coloring instance could work. First we need a lemma, the Parity Condition, which will be used for the reduction.

The Parity Condition

Let be a cubic graph, which is 3 edge colored. Let and be subsets vertices and edges of . connects vertices and . Denote as the number of colors in in . Then the lemma exhibits

$$k_1 \equiv k_2 \equiv k_3 mod 2$$

(Holyer, 1981)

Construction Consideration

As we’ve already mentioned the goal is to show if a 3SAT instance C is satisfiable, the constructed graph is 3-edge-colorable. consists of components that have certain tasks to fulfill and informations are transported through pair of edges. A pair of edges in represents the value , if the edges have the same color, else the edges have distinct colors. //TODO:draw graph

This component has 5 incoming edges . If this components is 3-edge-colorable, one of the edge pairs or have the same color and the remaining edges have different colors. This can be easily checked with the Parity Condition . If the pairs and are interpreted as input and output, this component changes the -value as the input to the -value and vice versa. So this corresponds to the negation.

This next component’s responsibility is to to test the satisfaction. The satisfaction component can only be 3-edge-colored, if the three input edges do not represent the -value.

And finally a variable setting component is needed. This has one pair of edges representing literals and .

Theorem

With the defined components we can finally prove the following theorem. The problem of determining whether a cubic graph has a chromatic index of 3 or 4 is NP-complete. (Holyer, 1981) For the prove the negation and the satisfaction component are needed. There exists a certificate for the cubic graph, so the problem lies in NP. Given a 3SAT instance the goal is to construct a graph . So for each variable of the clause a variable setting component is used and for each clause a satisfaction component is connected with edges between the satisfaction component and each variable setting component of each clause.
